Crumb.description: This is a popular pirate bar in the bywater area. It's famous for its fun atmosphere, cool drinks, and hearty steaks. Stop in and stay awhile.

Crumb.name: Ignatius Reilly
Crumb.description: This person made famous in The Confederacy of Dunces has a statue guarding the gates to the quarter.
Crumb.text: Ignatius Reilly has been found
Crumb.clue: New Orleans Don Quixote made famous by John Toole
Crumb.media_text: Ignatius Jacques Reilly is something of a modern Don Quixote—eccentric, idealistic, and creative, sometimes to the point of delusion.[2] In his foreword to the book, Walker Percy describes Ignatius as a 'slob extraordinary, a mad Oliver Hardy, a fat Don Quixote, a perverse Thomas Aquinas rolled into one'. He disdains modernity, particularly pop culture. The disdain becomes his obsession: he goes to movies in order to mock their perversity and express his outrage with the contemporary world's lack of 'theology and geometry'. He prefers the scholastic philosophy of the Middle Ages, and the Early Medieval philosopher Boethius in particular.[4] However, he also enjoys many modern comforts and conveniences and is given to claiming that the rednecks of rural Louisiana hate all modern technology which they associate with progress. The workings of his pyloric valve play an important role in his life, reacting strongly to incidents in a fashion that he likens to Cassandra in terms of prophetic significance.

Crumb.name: The Fat Man
Crumb.description: This artist is a New Orleans rhythmn and Blues legend, with famous songs such as 'I'm Walkin', and 'Whole Lotta Loving'
Crumb.text: You Found musicians square
Crumb.clue: This famous New Orleans musicians can be found nestled with several friends.
Crumb.media_text: Musical Legends Park is centrally located at 311 Bourbon Street. The heart of the Park is a tribute to New Orleans Musical Legends and includes a series of commemorative displays, plaques and artwork. The Park provides a warm, intimate escape for local and visiting music lovers. Musicians are invited to play for outdoor audiences. Performances are free to the public.

Crumb.name: And He's Feelin Fine
Crumb.description: Find the Big Chief of Professor Longhair fame
Crumb.text: You should hear the music by now
Crumb.clue: This Mardi Gras Indian is found celebrating still today in the park of a famous musician found with Fats Domino
Crumb.media_text: From age four in 1937 to his death in 1998, Donald Harrison Sr. embraced the tradition of New Orleans' Mardi Gras Indians. As Big Chief of the Guardian of the Flames, he led with both wisdom and passion. This biography of this remarkable man is based on more than seventy interviews with his family and others he influenced.

Crumb.name: The Maid
Crumb.description: She was known as the heroine of France
Crumb.text: You should hear the music by now
Crumb.clue: Find the Maid of Orleans
Crumb.media_text: The uncrowned King Charles VII sent Joan to the siege of Orléans as part of a relief mission. She gained prominence after the siege was lifted only nine days later. Several additional swift victories led to Charles VII's coronation at Reims. This long-awaited event boosted French morale and paved the way for the final French victory.
